We desire to place no obstacle in the way of any honorable senator who desires to inspect the sites, in order that he may be able to give a vote on any question which may arise concerning the location of the Federal Capital.

- I desire to ask the Vice-President of the Executive Council, without notice, whether a communication has been received from the Premier of New South Wales with reference to not proceeding further at the present time with a measure relating to Federal Quarantine ; and, if so, whether the Government are prepared to accede to the request for a reasonable delay?
- I believe that some representation has been made, but it is not within my personal knowledge, and therefore I would suggest to my honorable friend that he should give notice of the question.

- I desire to ask the Vice-President of the Executive Council, without notice, whether he can state, either now or when the Judiciary Bill is brought on, if the Government intend in that or any other Bill to take any step to prevent appeals from a single Justice of a State Supreme Court to the High Court?

- It is certainly not our present intention to include a proposal of that kind in the Judiciary Bill. The Government have not considered the subject-matter of my honorable friend's question, and I would suggest that he should give notice of it, so that I may have an opportunity to get a reply.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 17th July(vide. page 585) on motion by Senator Best -

quote.para: That the Bill be now read a second time.

subdebate.1.para: Senator Sir JOSIAH SYMON (South Australia) [3.17]. - I think it would have been better, if these two Bills - the Judiciary Bill and the one relating to income

*ax on Commonwealth salaries and allowances - had been dealt with in the ordinary way, separately. I believe that honorable senators will agree with me in that respect when we come to consider them in detail. But as it is the wish of my honorable friend, the Vice-President of the Executive Council, to deal with both' at the same time, and in the same debate, I defer to that wish, and am glad on this occasion to follow his example. At the same time, I may as well mention to honorable senators why it appears to me that it would have been more convenient to deal with the measures :separately. The two Bills are not, it appears to me, correlated in any way whatever. They are not the complement the one of the other. Each is independent of the other. One of these Bills might be enacted or rejected without affecting the other in the slightest degree.

talk.start.para: - I suggested dealing with them together for the purpose of convenience.

- My honorable friend assents to what I say, but he adds that it is a matter of convenience to deal with them together, as though I were reflecting upon his own desire in that respect. I am not reflecting upon that at all. But I differ entirely from him in the matter of convenience. The one Bill - the Salaries Bill, as I may call it for shortness - is a Bill to impose taxation upon certain persons or classes of persons who have been declared under the Constitution to be exempt from that taxation. The other Bill is one, as I think, to take away powers from States Courts which they already under the Constitution enjoy, and which they were intended to enjoy ; and to that extent, in my view, to impair the status of the States Courts, which the framers of the Constitution were distinctly anxious to preserve. So that the two Bills are really for entirely different - in point of fact, entirely opposite - purposes. And I doubt very much - in fact, I do not suppose that it will be suggested - whether it will be possible, except as regards discussing the two Bills together in one speech instead of two, to deal with the two together in Committee.
- Hear, hear.

- Or to -deal with them contemporaneously. Therefore, it appears to me that we are dealing with two measures at the same time, which are entirely distinct in their nature and intention, and that .it will be necessary for us ,to apply our minds to each of them separately. Consequently, in the remarks which I propose to offer for the consideration of the Senate, I shall deal with the Bills separately, one following the other. But there are two points of similarity which I desire to indicate. The first is that they probably owe their origin to the same cause. That is to say, in all probability they come before us now in consequence of the same set of circumstances. Another point of similarity is that both of these Bills appear to be the outcome, according to a statement contained in the exceedingly interesting speech which Senator Best delivered, of advice or direction from the members, or some of the members, of the High Court, in consequence of whose decision - without reflecting upon the decision itself - this difficulty has arisen. My honorable friend, Senator Best, laid great stress upon that in introducing the Bills. In one place, after quoting the advice that was given by the learned Chief Justice in regard to the method of escape from the consequences of his own judgment, he said this-

quote.para: Thus it will be seen that when the power of the Parliament to deal with legislation of this kind is challenged -

subdebate.1.para: That is ' to say, my honorable friend considered, and the Government of which he is a member contemplated, and, I think, were wise in contemplating, that this kind of legislation, which amounts to putting patches upon the Constitution, might be challenged - would lead to litigation. But what did he rely upon in reference to that anticipated challenge? This -

quote.para: I am referring, of course, to the Commonwealth Salaries Bill. My first answer is that we have the authority of the High Court for enacting it. That is good enough for me, and I think it ought to be good enough for Parliament.

subdebate.1.para: Now, I beg leave to offer the very strongest objection to any such position as that being submitted to any Parliament, or being offered as a justification or excuse for the introduction of legislation into this Parliament which may 'be the subject of question and litigative action hereafter. It ought not to be good enough for the Government or for Parliament. It is an unusual thing, as, I think, every honorable senator, and certainly every lawyer, will agree, for any tribunal to suggest or advise particular legislation as an escape from the consequences of its own judgment. The duty of a Court is to expound and apply the law as it is. It has nothing to do with the consequences, whatever they may be. Its duty is solely to expound and apply the law. It is not its duty to recommend legislation to Parliament, to anticipate its own decisions in respect of that legislation, or to do that which may in time - I ask the serious attention of honorable senators to this - become a precedent, and may develop into a direction or a kind of dictation which Parliament would undoubtedly resent. But the great mischief is this : It is obvious that the statement of the Chief Justice is being relied upon by the Executive Government to diminish their own responsibility ; and not merely to diminish their own responsiblity, but it is being used as a prophetic judgment of the Court before whom that challenge of this legislation must, at least may, come to be heard. Now, I say that that sort of thing, if permitted, would be disastrous to our judicial system. I regret the suggestion for another reason also. My honorable friend, Senator Best, in another connexion used the expression obiter dictum. This is worse than any obiter dictum. It is a pronouncement which is not binding even upon the learned Judge who used the words, and took upon himself to give the advice. When even he himself has this challenge brought under the notice of the Court it will be for him, irrespective of what he has previously said, to consider the arguments that are addressed to him, and to come to a conclusion upon those arguments, and- upon the view submitted as to whether or not this measure infringes the Constitution - whether it is valid or whether it is not. Can he do that now with an open mind ? But we have another learned Judge saying most distinctly that as to one of these points he does not agree, and as to another point he reserves his opinion. What a position members of this Parliament are asked to put themselves in ! They are invited to disregard the constitutional objections which may arise in their own minds, and solve the doubt as to the authority of Parliament to legislate in this particular way, on the ground, as my honorable friend put it, that a Judge without argument and gratuitously, has already offered an opinion as to the validity of this prospective legislation. I deeply regret that suggestion. I shall not say that we ought to resent it, because I do not wish to use any words of that character, but it is a humiliating position for this Parliament to be placed in if the question arises for our solution, and we are to say that we can pass this proposed law, whatever doubts we may ourselves entertain, because a Judge or Judges, without argument, have expressed the opinion that we have authority whilst other Judges take the contrary view. On this, I would add that if there is one thing plainer than another in connexion with the Supreme Court of the United States, it is that that exalted tribunal will not give any abstract opinion, that it declines to give any prophetic opinion, and that it will not decide any question, constitutional or otherwise, unless it comes before it in a concrete shape, in the form of a lawsuit between parties who happen to be affected. I say that is a fine rule. Honorable senators and I are concerned in this matter. We may or may not 'feel that as we are immune from State taxation in respect of our allowances, they ought to be, by some such legislation as is now proposed, made subject to that taxation, and if so, are1 we to be prevented or intimidated from challenging this measure and claiming the right to argue the whole question before the Privy Council or the Judges of the High Court who may have to determine it, by reason of an anticipatory expression of opinion that was not called for in any way whatever by the circumstances of the case? The two points to which I have referred are the only points of similarity between the; two Bills now before the Senate - that they were the outcome, I shall not say probably, but without any doubt, of the same set of circumstances, although they relate to totally different matters, and that the doubts of Parliament as to our competence to pass valid Acts taking away this immunity from persons declared to be free of this particular taxation under the Constitution, are to be removed by an anticipatory judgment, without hearing, parties, without argument, and without that consideration which is essential to the adequate administration of justice, volunteered by one or more Judges who may hereafter have this very question before them for argument and decision. I do not think that many of the questions which have been alluded to, as to the powers of appeal and so on, arise for our consideration now. Senator Best discussed them at great length, and dealt with a multitude of citations relative to the! powers of appeal and so on, but with these, except in so far as they have a bearing, and no very important bearing, on matters involved in these two. Bills, I do not think it is necessary to deal. But I wish to make it clear that I do not at all assent to the proposition my honorable friend has put forward in his interesting address. The honorable and learned senator referred tq the question of the conflict of law. That there is a conflict no one can doubt, but I do not think it arises quite in the way which Senator Best supposes. The awkward, I will not say intolerable, position, is in my judgment not due to the Privy Council, but rather to the High Court. To whoever it may be due, I must say that I do not agree with the following statement made by Senator Best-

quote.para: This unfortunate and indeed ludicrous position is intolerable; and Parliament has the responsibility of relieving the community with the least possible delay.

subdebate.1.para: I venture to think that Parliament has not that responsibility at all. If Parliament could do it, that would be another matter, but we have the authority of the Chief Justice of the High Court himself, for saying that the powers of appeal to the High Court do not arise from or depend upon the Judiciary Act at all, which is the work of Parliament, but depend on and arise from the Constitution, with which Parliament cannot deal by means of an ordinary Act. My honorable and learned friend went on to say -

quote.para: The question is whether Parliament is content that we should have two final Courts of Appeal of co-ordinate jurisdiction, for the purpose of interpreting the Constitution and questions arising under it.

subdebate.1.para: That is not the question. I venture to say that there is no such conflict at all. I have seen no evidence in anything that has taken place of a conflict of that character. There is only one Court to interpret the Constitution when a question of that find comes before that Court. The one difficulty is as to which Court is the final judge as to what are questions between the Commonwealth and any State or States inter se.Senator Best said -

quote.para: We find that what we regarded as the High Court, whose duty it was to decide on the questions I have indicated is not the sole and final arbiter ; on the contrary, the Privy Council has asserted that it has certain powers, with the result that we have now . two final Courts of co-ordinate jurisdiction to deal with the same subjects.

subdebate.1.para: Now the Privy Council has not asserted anything of the kind. It has decided a matter brought before it in the ordinary way of litigation, and which was considered by the Judge who sent it there, and by the Privy Council, to be a matter within its competence, and on which it could decide - a matter which was not an appeal from the judgment of the High Court under section 74 of the Constitution at all. The Privy Council dealt with that matter, believing and declaring that it was - as I think it was, though that does not amount to anything except that we are all entitled to express our own opinion' - a matter as entirely within the competence of the Privy Council as any other question that might come before it. The Privy Council, without seeking to diminish by one iota the high status and functions of the High Court of Austria, decided that question, and if I may say so, decided it, in consonance, at any rate with the universal feeling of Australia that justice was done.

talk.start.para: - But in doing so did not the Privy Council set themselves up as interpreters of the Constitution?
- No, I think not.
- They overrode Australian1 law as laid down by the High Court.

- What they did was to decide a question which was properly before them. The Privy Council is not to be subordinate to the High Court. Senator Best says that they overrode the law, but if the High Court gives an expression of opinion or a decision on a matter with which it is competent for the Privy Council to deal there is no overriding of the law if the Privy Council differs in opinion from the High Court.
- But does not the decision of the Privy Council show that in their judgment they are the final arbiters of constitutional questions ?

- Certainly not. They went in no way beyond the precise matter before them. All it shows is that the Privy Council considered that in that particular matter they were entitled to pronounce their judgment.
- That it was not a constitutional matter?
- That it was not an appeal upon a constitutional matter with which they were precluded from dealing. I agree with them on that point, though that may be of no consequence.
- Does the honorable and learned senator say that they decided that this was not a matter inter se.
- In effect they did say that the subject of appeal was not a judgment of the High Court in a matter inter se.
- I shall be glad if the honorable and learned senator can show me anything in proof of that.

- I shall be glad to do so, but I should like to be allowed to go on in my own way. I do not wish to be long, but I do wish to put the matter as clearly as I possibly can. I say at present that I do not assent to Senator Best's proposition at all. I respectfully emphasize the statement that I do not consider that the status or dignity or any of the just and legitimate functions of the High Court of Australia, under the terms of the Constitution, are impaired or lessened by the judgment of the Privy Council in that case. I say that the question now before us is not as to whether the High Court is or is not the sole and final arbiter of the Constitution, or whether the judgment of the Privy Council has destroyed that position, in the words which Senator Best made use of in a later part of his speech, and which I think ought to be dissented from -

quote.para: I shall sum up by saying that the decision in the case of Webb v. Outtrim has destroyed the status of the High Court as an integral part of our Constitution, -

subdebate.1.para: I deny it. unsettled the respective powers of the Commonwealth and States and destroyed the finality of the High Court.

I say it has done nothing of the kind, and if it did I say that the whole of that is irrelevant. It might influence or inflame our minds to deal with it as a relevant case, but even if that be so, neither of the Bills before us will alter the position. In fact the Bill with regard to salaries, as I hope to show in a word or two, is an affirmation of the judgment of the Privy Council. It declares, in effect, that the judgment of, the Privy Council is just, that there should be no exemption and no immunity. I do not say at present whether there ought or ought not to be, but is not that what the Bill says? Is not" that what we in this Parliament are called upon to do? It is not the judgment of the Privy Council that affects the status of the High Court. It is this Bill. It is this Bill which -says "You, the High Court, decline to follow the opinion of the' Privy Council, which is consonant with what the community as a whole believe to-' be just. Parliament says that it should* be followed." That is the effect of this' Salaries Bill, and, therefore, we may well ask what is it that, to use again the language of my honorable friend the Vice-' President of the Executive Council, " has destroyed the status of the High Court as-' an integral part of our Constitution, unsettled the respective powers of the Commonwealth and the States, and destroyed! the finality of the High Court" ? According to my honorable friend, it is the judgment which we now, by this Bill, are asked to affirm. It is the most novel situation; I have ever heard of. If the Government had asked us to pass a Bill to confirm* the judgment of the High Court, if such a thing had been possible, that in all probability would have been consistent.

talk.start.para: - Did not the Uni-. ted States Congress do over and over again exactly what we are doing? Did! they not do it in the case of the judgment of the United States Supreme Court> in the case of Dred Scott?

- I think we will leave Dred Scott out of it at: present. I do not want to import more ' American notions into this than I car* help. My honorable friend has rather' misunderstood the point which I have been, putting, and that is - I think he will agree with me - that the position as put to us by the Government is either that the High> Court is right and the Privy Council wrong, or that the High Court, having the power, has decided wrongly, and1 the Privy Council, not having the power, ' has done justice, and we are asked by an Act of this Parliament to adopt the decision of the Privy Council, and reject the decision of the High Court. If that be so, I venture to think that it is a very strong: argument for saying that instead of restricting the avenues of access to the Privy Council, we ought to widen them. Still,, that is not the question before us. I lis- 'tened with very great interest to the speech of my honorable friend, Senator St. Ledger, and to his account of the history of the appellate provisions of the Constitution. I shall give a short version of that history ' myself, which does not run quite together with the version which my honorable friend gave. History, 'of course, is very often' surrounded with a considerable haze, and the haze' lends enchantment at times to the_ history. My honorable friend's version of the history had a good deal of that poetical haze about it. This increased its attractiveness, but what it gained in attractiveness, I fear it rather lost in accuracy. [ will put the history very shortly, and I think my honorable friend will see from what I state as an actor in those events that the Convention at any rate proceeded upon principles which were a little different from those which he inferred from the actual results.
- I shall bow to the honorable senator's version, of course.

- In some features there is not very much difference between us. We need not dwell long upon that, because this proposed legislation is not to settle difficulties at all between the relative powers of the two Courts. Those powers are not in controversy before us now. I say these things as a kind of apology to honorable senators for not following in detail some of those matters with which they are quite as familiar as I am. We are not re-adjusting the powers of appeal. We are not asked here now for any reason to limit the powers of one tribunal or to extend the powers of the other. If we were asked, of course we could not do it, because those powers themselves depend upon the Constitution, and not upon any Act of this Parliament. It is of less moment again, because, as I have ventured to say already, the just and legitimate scope and status of the High Court under the Constitution is not, in my judgment, imperilled at all. The reason of that i's that the appellate jurisdiction of the High Court is given by the Constitution and not by the Judiciary Act, and is removed in that way from our interference. In very shortly stating the bit of history that may be material in connexion with these two Bills, I wish to say, first, that there is no sacred halo or mystery about the jurisdiction of the High Court. People are very often in the habit of using language in connexion with the High Court as though it were a mysterious or sacred body. It is nothing of the kind. Its functions; under the Constitution are simply those of a court of law to decide cases. Our Constitution is an Imperial Act of Parliament, assented to by the three Estates of the Realm - the King, the Lords, and the Commons - in the same way as the Acts of the Commonwealth are assented to by the King through his agent, the Governor-General, the Senate, and the House of Representatives, and in exactly the same way as the Acts of the States are assented to by the King, . through his representative, the House of Assembly and the Legislative Council. The High Court, under our Imperial Act of Parliament, which we rightly, describe as the Constitution, is simply a court of law created to decide cases, with certain limitations as to appeals to the superior tribunal of the Empire, the Privy Council, just as there are other limitations upon appeals, such as the limitation of amount, and the limitation that security, differing in kind according to the nature of the case, must be given. All those are limitations, and there are other limitations upon the power of appeal under our Constitution, but the Privy Council is still the ultimate Court of Appeal of the Empire. It is still the highest Court of the Empire. _ I wish to say here most emphatically that the Privy Council is a most august and learned tribunal, worthy of standing, as it does now, not even second to the House of Lords, in the foremost position among the tribunals of the Empire of which we are a part. There was undoubtedly a time, a good many years ago, when the position pf the Privy Council was different from what it is now. But the Privy Council to-day, so far as regards its -personnel for the adjudication of cases, is absolutely as great a Court as - I am not sure that it is not, for reasons which I need not enter into now, a greater Court than - the House of Lords. Whether we differ from it or not, I think we shall all agree that no Court need hesitate for a moment to follow, or think that its dignity is impaired or its usefulness lessened by following, the decision of such a tribunal. Most jealous as I am of the powers of our own Court - and I want to show that the provisions as they now stand in the Constitution are not those to which I assented - I think that the judgment delivered by Mr. Justice Higgins in the recent case of the Commissioner of Taxes of New South Wales v. Baxter, to which free allusion has been made, contained a sound, wise statement of the constitutional position of the High Court of Australia. It is a mistake, which is not calculated to strengthen its powers or to enlarge its capacity for exercising the great functions reposed in it, that efforts in any direction should be made to alter that: position or place it on the .same footing, which it does not occupy under the particular terms of our Constitution, as the Supreme Court of the United States. One radical difference - I do not know whether Mr. Justice Higgins referred to it or not, but I think we ought all to be indebted to him for his exposition of that particular point - is that the status of the High Court is simply that of a court of law, created by an Imperial Statute, and dispensing justice as any other court might, but with a further limitation of the rights of appeal to the higher and superior tribunal. There is a radical difference from the position of the United States Supreme Court under the Constitution in this respect : that that Court - and all of us who had to do with the framing of the Constitution recognised the fact - literally stands for the King under our system. It is not necessary to make a qualification for the purpose of the views I am submitting. As the Privy Council pointed out, and as is apparent to every one, the Congress of the United States legislate as they please, uncontrolled by the States, and the States legislate uncontrolled by the Federal authority. There is no King who is part of the system as there is under the British Constitution. The King is a part of the legislative authority under our system. No Bill of this Parliament, or of a State Parliament is worth the paper it is printed on without the assent of the King or his representative. That is not so in the United States, where each State legislates as it pleases. Owing to that gap, so to speak, there was no controlling power over the States, and the only power that could fill the gap was some such body as the Supreme Court of the United States with power to interfere as widely as it thought fit with the legislation of both the Federal Congress and the States. The essential radical difference is that, the one is a republic and the other is a monarchy. We are simply a part of a monarchy, and in the Convention we sought to the best of our ability to assimilate as far as we could the position, but as we recognised over and over again absolute assimilation was impossible, because we could not get absolute assimilation between republican and monarchical institutions. That is one radical and fundamental difference in the two situations which ought to be remembered, and which in one aspect was dwelt on by the

subdebate.1.para: Privy Council with regard to the doctrine of implied prohibitions which, as Mr. Justice Isaacs said when at the Bar in the earlier cases of Deakin and Lyne was invented - that is his expression - by the Supreme Court of the United States, because of the position I have pointed out, and to extend that controlling influence which did not otherwise exist under the American system, but which, of course, exists under our system. Let me anticipate for a moment another matter, which has been referred to more than once, and which, has been widely canvassed, and that is, the so-called interference by a State with the conduct of the Commonwealth Government. Such a thing could not be tolerated. We have first - it is like the adage to first catch the hare - to show that there is some interference. For example, if a Bill were passed by a State Parliament professing to take control of the fortifications within the State, of course it would not be assented to for a moment. With us it is a case of one King. That particular part of the legislative power of the whole of the British Empire is common to Commonwealth and to State. We must be sensible beings when Ave are dealing Avith these things, and we cannot assume for a moment that that particular part of the legislative power of the Commonwealth would assent to an interference Avith the power of a State Government

talk.start.para: - But the question of assent would not rest Avith either the High Court or the Privy Council. It would rest with the State Governor.
- Certainly.
- Suppose that he exercised his power, and assented to the Bill ?
- Then there it would have to remain.
- That is where the High Court comes in.

- That is, as I am venturing to point out, where the High Court does not come in. What I am pointing out is that under our Constitution, although there are implications from the words, of course, there is no scope, to such an extent, for such a doctrine as was invented in America. There is no need for it, and we must remember that that implied prohibition is not a prohibition implied from words in the Constitution. It is something altogether outside the Constitution. In the Constitution there are no words from which we are to imply - -that is one kind of implication. We get certain words which express something, and carry with them a certain implication, but this prohibition is a separate and independent doctrine which was framed or invented to meet a situation in the "United States, which is not paralleled under our Constitution. But it is not necessary to dwell upon it. I think it is a far-fetched and fantastic doctrine, certainly as applied here. Still, they have it in America, and have followed it. We do not need such a doctrine here. I do not wish to canvass the judgment of the High Court in that respect at all, but only desire to point out the difference between the two systems, and the two Constitutions, and to show that it does not follow that because it was thought necessary in America to create this doctrine of implied prohibitions-
- Or implied powers.

- Yes, it does not follow that because it was thought necessary in America to create the doctrine of implied .prohibitions or implied powers to the extent which they did, it would be equally necessary or equally proper to introduce it under our quite different monarchical system of government. Remembering that radical difference, I now refer to the position of these provisions. First of all, the language of section 74 of the Constitution is not that of the Convention. I shall show what language it is. Whatever ambiguity or confusion, if any, or difficulty of application there may be in connexion with that language it is not due to the Convention. In the next place - remembering, as 'I have ventured to submit from my point of view, that the High Court is simply a Court of law under an Imperial Act of Parliament, with it may be an additional limitation on appeals; remembering that, what we strove to do in the Convention, and what I particularly wished, was to have a much stronger limitation on the appeals - it was never dreamt for a moment that owing" to the particular position of the Constitution we could deal with the High Court in any other way than as a Court of law created by an Imperial Act. But we desired very greatly to increase the limitations on the power of appeal to the superior court - the Privy Council - and we wished to do it to the entire exclusion of appeals in all domestic or Australian national affairs.
- Irrespective of where they originated.

- Irrespective of everything. I shall show the extreme length to which I was prepared to go, and to .which we did go. I thought then, as now, that there were only two courses to prevent difficulty and trouble. One was to permit unrestricted appeals, or to practically end them. The view of the Judiciary Committee of the Convention, of which I had the honour to be chairman, was that any middle course was calculated to lead to trouble, that if we were to put in qualifications, the more we put in the more we should leave matters to be determined by some tribunal, and it was diK cult to distinguish which tribunal should determine them. Under section 74, as it now stands - without pronouncing a positive view one way or the other about it - it is difficult to see which Court, under the terms of the Constitution, is to determine the question of when a dispute is a dispute as to constitutional powers inter se between Commonwealth and State. That power is a preliminary matter. It has not been vested in the High Court, not in express terms. If a matter comes before the Privy Council, they take the view that it is not a dispute as to limits inter se, or that it is not a judgment of the High Court as to limits inter se, it is difficult to see why they should not. Or they may say it is a matter between the Commonwealth and a State as to limits inter se, or that only such disputes as these are precluded from going before the Privy Council when they arise on a judgment of the High Court. All these matters arise on language which has been used, and which, unlike the language which was used in the Convention, lends itself to differences and controversies in the way I have suggested. Therefore I think that honorable senators will agree with the Convention, at any rate will agree with its Judiciary Committee, that in dealing with this matter it was better either to have unrestricted appeals, subject only to special leave, which is a mere matter of regulation, or to practically put an end to them. I also wish to say that the broad ground upon which it was desired to do that - although discussion took place, and in the heat of the argument things were said and unsaid - was not because of any inferiority, or any suspicion of the kind, in respect of that great Imperial tribunal, the Privy Council as now constituted, but because we were endeavouring to take the first step in Australia towards union and nationhood, and we considered that it was right as an attribute of the nation which we were seeking to establish that it should dispense final justice to its own citizens.
- We did not all think that in the Convention.

- My honorable friend quite rightly reminds me that the clause was carried against the views of some of the members of the Convention. But the broad ground upon which it was carried was that we were elevating ourselves - elevating Australia - into the position of a nation. That was the great inspiration we had; and one of the first things which we considered that we ought to try to do, was to dispense our own justice finally. I say that because of certain remarks which I regret should have been made by the Chief Justice of the High Court, reflecting upon the Privy Council, and attributing to us in the Convention reasons for the course that we took, which were not the real fundamental reasons upon which we. acted. Following out that plan, and on that basis, the Judiciary Committee of the Convention at Adelaide, and again at the beginning of the session in Melbourne, recommended a clause in the following form' -

quote.para: No appeal shall be allowed to the Queen in Council from any Court of any State, or from the High Court, or any other Federal Court.

subdebate.1.para: It will be seen that appeal to the Privy Council was to be absolutely put an end to from the Courts of the States as well as from the High Court. There was to be no appeal to the Privy Council at all -

quote.para: Except that the Queen may in any matter in which the public interests of the Commonwealth or of any State or of any other part of Her Majesty's Dominions are concerned - that is, Imperial interests which we were all agreed should be made an exception - grant leave to appeal to the Queen in Council from the High Court.

subdebate.1.para: Nothing could have been clearer, I venture to think, than that ; and that stamps what the sentiment of the Convention was. It meant literally that in all domestic concerns, if I may use that expression - in everything concerning the interests of the Australian Commonwealth, about to be created- there should be no appeal, but that we would settle such matters for good or ill for ourselves. The clause in that form was again passed at the beginning of the session in Melbourne.

talk.start.para: - Did it not provide that there was to be no appeal on constitutional matters only?

- No; there was to be no appeal on any matter, with the one exception stated. My honorable friend, Senator Dobson,, was a most strenuous opponent of the clause. We* all respected his views, but they were not the views of the majority. The intention was, as I have said, that there should be no appeal, not merely from the High Court, but from any Court of a State. Indeed, appeals to the Privy Council were all swept away.
- Unless Imperial interests were involved.

- I have said again and again that in all domestic affairs of Australia - using that expression in the largest sense - there was to be no appeal. Then came an amendment. There was a strenuous fight - and rightly if the question was to be re-opened at all - to retain the power of appeal; and' accordingly towards the close of the Melbourne session our lamented and greatly esteemed friend, the late Sir Joseph Abbott, one of the representatives of New South Wales in the Convention, moved an amendment. That was after the clause as I have read it had been twice confirmed by the Convention. He moved the insertion in the clause which made the judgment of the High Court final and conclusive, of the words -

quote.para: Saving any right that Her Majesty may be pleased to exercise by virtue of her royal prerogative.

subdebate.1.para: As indicating the grounds upon which Sir Joseph Abbott moved that amendment, and as- evidencing the grounds upon which we rested our claim as Australians to dispense final justice, he took exception to my having said -

quote.para: We are creating a nation which is to be self-contained, self-sufficing in every possible respect.

subdebate.1.para: Those were my words, and Sir Joseph Abbott said, " I deny that," and so on. That amendment, of course, would have permitted appeals in every case. It would have been the exact opposite of what we intended. The amendment was debated, and ultimately was carried by a small majority - of. I think, four. At a later stage I moved a further amendment to insert the words -

quote.para: Not involving the interpretation of the Constitution of the Commonwealth or of a State.

subdebate.1.para: Now, honorable senators will see how much trouble would have been saved if those words had been adopted. What we had in mind was that we were formulating a written Constitution; and there could be no doubt whatever that what was being excluded from the power of appeal was the interpretation of the written instrument, not implied prohibitions, not fanciful things outside the Constitution, - and which depend upon the view that each Judge or each Court may take on any particular occasion.

talk.start.para: - Which may depend upon the state of the Judge's liver, perhaps !

- I will not say that; Judges are not supposed to have livers - at any rate not disturbing ones. That amendment was carried. It was embodied in a form which set out the various clauses as amended. It formed part, of clauses 73 and 75A, and, as amended, it read in this way -

quote.para: Notwithstanding anything in the last section, an appeal to the Queen in Council from a Court of a State, or from the High Court, or from any other Federal Court, shall not be allowed in any matter in which the interpretation of this Constitution or of the Constitution of a State is involved, unless in any such matter the public interests of any part of Her Majesty's Dominions other than the Commonwealth or a State are involved.

subdebate.1.para: That swept away the right of appeal from a Court of a State and from the High Court, in that particular class of matters. But then the clause passed on to the Drafting Committee, of which two of the present Justices of the High Court were members. Strangely enough, the Drafting Committee altered it so that it no longer extended to appeals from the Supreme Courts of the States1. It left appeals direct from the States Courts' to the Privy Council just as before. I think that was an accident. I will not say of the distinguished men who were members of that Committee that what they did was careless, or anything of that kind, but it was unfortunate. These matters only came before the Convention a day or two - if so much - before the Convention broke up. Then my honorable and learned friend, Mr. Glynn, rose to point out the grave alteration with a view to having it rectified. But at that stage, when a large number of the members of the Convention had departed, for their homes, to have re-opened the question on these so-called drafting amendments would probably have imperilled the work which the Convention had done. It might have imperilled the Bill altogether. An alteration was deprecated ; it was not made ; and so the clause appeared in the Bill as submitted to the referendum in this shape. It was the celebrated clause 74 -

quote.para: No appeal shall be permitted to the Queen in Council in any matter involving the interpretation of this Constitution or of the Constitution of a State, unless the public interests of some part of Her Majesty's Dominions other than the Commonwealth or a State are involved.

subdebate.1.para: That left out the express words taking the right of appeal away in respect of the decisions of the States Courts. At the referendum it was adopted in that shape. If it had stood like that I venture to think we should never have had the trouble that has recently arisen. I cannot think that there would have been any difficulty in determining that the interpretation of the Constitution meant anything but-the interpretation of the written instrument. The section as it now stands is, I think, very different. It is-

quote.para: No appeal shall be permitted to the Queen in Council from a decision of the High Court upon any question, howsoever arising, as to the limits inter se of the constitutional powers of the Commonwealth and those of any State or States, or as to the limits inter se of the constitutional powers of any two or more States, unless the High Court shall certify that the question is one which ought to be determined by Her Majesty in Council.

subdebate.1.para: Then there is the exception that -

quote.para: This Constitution shall not impair any right which the Queen may be pleased to exercise by virtue of Her Royal prerogative to grant special leave to appeal from the High Court to Her Majesty in Council.

subdebate.1.para: Honorable senators are aware that when that clause, as I have read it, and as it was carried at the referendum by the people of Australia, went to England, and the Bill containing that .provision went before the Imperial Executive and the Imperial Parliament, art attack was made upon* it. That attack was in order that it should be, if not struck out, at least so altered that an unrestricted power of appeal should be preserved. An alteration was made, and no one gave greater ' assistance to the attack that was made on that provision as assented to by the people of Australia, than the present Chief Justice of the High Court of

Australia himself. It has to be remembered that, no doubt rightly, according to his judgment, every effort was made by him, occupying at the time a very elevated position, as he does now, in order, as many of us thought, to thwart the wishes and intention of the people of Australia in regard to this right of appeal, and to preserve the appeal to the Privy Council which has now apparently been found inconvenient.

talk.start.para: - But he was not one of the delegates.

- No, unhappily, or rather happily. He was not one of the delegates, and his efforts were made with those of others by methods which were not direct, but which had an influence with the authorities in England I think they ought not io have had, and which largely brought about the change in the phraseology of the section which has caused a great deal of the difficulty.
- I think he was consulted unofficially, and also officially.
- By whom?

- I took a part which I do not regret in the defence, in a small way, of what I believed to be the right of the Australian people to settle their own Constitution! for themselves. I took up the position that I declined to admit that the Imperial Parliament or Government, or anybody else, had a right to alter one line or one sentiment in the Constitution as adopted bv the people of Australia. I deprecated and described the efforts which were made by those who were not delegates as intrigues behind the backs of the delegates.
- If they were not delegates, I should say they had no right to interfere.

- Certainly not. I do not wish to dwell upon that now. The efforts to which I refer were made, I am sure, in the belief that they were justified, and that the Privy Council was a great Court adequate to the determination of all these questions. I have no reason to doubt that they were made because of a belief that the Privy Council was an august and learned Court, more competent, in the judgment of the persons making these efforts, than any Court that could be constituted in Australia. _I did not agree with that view, but I attribute to those who made those efforts a belief that the Privy Council was a Court with sufficient knowledge of the laws of Australia and of the Empire, to do justice in respect of any such appeal. It is, therefore, with great pain, and with some astonishment, that I read the opinions that are now expressed by Sir Samuel Griffith about this tribunal to which he, seven years ago, thought all these appeals should go. I find, in the judgment which has been alluded to in Baxter's case, disparaging attacks made upon the Privy Council, which I think ought to have been avoided. At page 13 of the published judgment, I find this statement -

quote.para: It was common knowledge, not only that the decisions of the Judicial Committee in the Canadian cases had not given widespread satisfaction -

talk.start.para: - Is the honorable senator quoting Sir Samuel Griffith?

- Yes. I take exception to that statement, and I can speak from personal knowledge. I have lately been in Canada, and I found, because I made inquiries on the subject, that there is there the greatest satisfaction with the appellate jurisdiction of the Privy Council. That does not affect the principle for which I have always contended, that is to say, the principle bf a National Court. I know that Bourinot, the great constitutional writer in Canada, has eulogised the decisions of that Court over and over again, and has attributed to the decisions of the Privy Council - because we must be fair - a beneficent effect in soothing the susceptibilities and overcoming the racial differences, as I may call them for want of a better term, arising from legislation on different matters, between the two different races which inhabit Lower Canada.. There is, therefore, no warrant for the statement I have quoted. The Chief Justice of the High Court went on to say - but also that the Constitution of the United States was a subject entirely unfamiliar to English lawyers, while to Australian publicists it was almost as familiar as the British Constitution. It was known that even if there should be any members of the Judicial Committee familiar with the subject -

subdebate.1.para: What a condescension that is - it was quite uncertain whether they would form members of a Board that might be called upon to determine a question on appeal from an Australian Court, by which it must necessarily be dealt with in the first instance.. It could not be predicted of the Board which would sit to entertain an appeal that it would be constituted with any regard to the special familiarity of its members with the subject.
And no disrespect is implied in saying that the eminent lawyers who constituted the Judicial Committee were not regarded -

By whom, I wonder - either as being familiar with the history or conditions of the remoter portions of the Empire, or as having any sympathetic understanding of the aspirations of the younger communities which had long enjoyed ' the privilege of self government.

When was this discovery made? Was this known when all those efforts were made to secure an unrestricted right of appeal to the Privy Council, or has this doubt arisen only now, when, to use the expression employed by Senator St. Ledger, there is a jealousy of the interference of the Privy Council with the jurisdiction of the High Court.

talk.start.para: - I used that expression in the legal, and not hi the ordinary, sense, because all Courts are jealous of their jurisdiction.
- Undoubtedly. At page 19 of the published judgment, I find this further statement -

quote.para: It is said that such a state of things as would follow from a difference of opinion between the Judicial Committee and the High Court would be intolerable. It would not perhaps have been extravagant to expect that the Judicial Committee would recognise the intention of the Imperial legislature to make the opinion of the High Court final in such matters. But that is their concern and not ours.
In our opinion the intention of the British legislature -

debate.para: It was not the intention of the British Legislature, but the intention of the people of Australia that was in question - was to substitute for a distant Court of uncertain composition imperfectly acquainted with Australian conditions, unlikely to be assisted by counsel familiar with those conditions, and whose decisions would be rendered many months, perhaps years, after its judgment had been invoked, an Australian Court, immediately available, constant in its composition, well versed in Australian history and conditions, Australian in its sympathies, and whose judgments, rendered as the occasion arose, would form a working code for the guidance of the Commonwealth.

There are many similar references, but, later on, the Chief Justice speaks of the Privy Council as confessing a lack of familiarity with the subject, and speaks of the appeal as - setting up an official in London, subject to political accidents, in place of the High Court, as the guardian of the Constitution.
I venture to think that it is undesirable that expressions of that sort should be used. They were not necessary in any way whatever in delivering a great judgment dealing with a great question.

talk.start.para: - Besides, they are erroneous.
- And at any rate, they do not come well from one who, seven years ago, sought to give unrestricted rights of appeal to that particular tribunal.
- They would have been perfectly in place in the Convention.

- Perfectly so in the Convention. The views of the Convention, which Senator Pearce's interjection reminds me were broad-based upon a national administration of justice, were sought, and sought successfully by Sir Samuel Griffith, to be undermined by views which could not' have been the views to which I have just referred if the efforts which were made were, as I am bound to believe they were, conscientiously undertaken. That is the short history of this provision. With its re- adjustment, its extension, or limitation, we are not now concerned. We have, as a result, several decisions of the High Court, and a decision of the Privy Council, and we are asked to do something, not to settle the possibility of a difference of that sort occurring again, but to give effect to judgments of a kind which are described as being not altogether in sympathy with Australian aspirations. We are asked to do something which shall give effect to the judgment of men who are described by the High Court as not being in sympathy with Australian aspirations, or with what I may call the sense of justice of Australia - and to legislatively declare it is the judgment of the Privy Council and not that of the High Court which is in conformity with the universal sense of justice in Australia that there shall be no privileged class in respect of this income taxation. It is certainly an extremely odd position, but that is where we are. How is it to be met ? This Bill says that a State cannot tax its own citizens or a certain class of them without the consent of the Federal Parliament, and it professes to give that consent. It is a very serious inroad, I venture to say upon - I do not want to use that much abused term " States rights " or anything like it, and in any case I do not think that defines what I mean - but upon what we have always regarded as a principle of self-government, that a State should be entitled to tax its own citizens. That is the plain simple way in which I view this question. One would expect to find something expressed in the Constitution to justify our assuming a right to interfere between the State and its citizens. We should, however, look for something expressed to enable this Parliament to make liable to taxation persons whom our High Court has said the Constitution exempts from liability. The situation itself is shortly this : The High Court decided in the cases of Deakin and Lyne that State citizens receiving salaries from the Commonwealth were exempt from State income tax in respect of such salaries; in fact, that the taxing power of a State over itS own citizens was paralyzed so far as regarded that portion of their property or income which consisted of salaries drawn from the sacred fountain of the Commonwealth Treasury. It was not denied that the Commonwealth servants are citizens' of the State in which they reside, receive the protection of the Government of that State, and share its benefits like all other citizens, yet, according to the judgment, they are to do so without paying one penny for it so far as the ' income tax is concerned. They pay for their food and their raiment, and there would seem to be no more reason in justice or principle why they should not pay their share for their police protection than for the other things they require in the State. The one is just as essential to the necessities of humane or civilized life as the other.
- They should also contribute towards the cost of the education of their children in the State.
- My honorable friend reminds me of that. One of the expenses in our State is free education. I do not know whether it is so in other States.
- In all the States.

- There is free education in all the States, and if there is only an income tax Federal public servants do not contribute towards the expenses of the education of .their own . children, if they send . them to the, State schools, simply because they happen to draw their salaries from the Commonwealth Treasury. I do not canvass these judgments at all ; we are not here for the purpose ; we are not a Court of Appeal, to say who is right or who is1 wrong; but we are here to look upon this matter as plain men, and I say that not merely is that the position to the plain man in the street, but it creates what I think, every one of us in these liberal days, detests - a privileged class set down in our midst. I do not wonder that at the time this decision caused considerable sensation. It shocked, as it might well do, the good sense and the sense of" justice of the community. There is another thing that the plain man in the street may remember in this connexion. The technical view that has been taken overlooks the fact that there is a dual citizenship ; that everyone of us is a citizen of the Commonwealth, but that we are also citizens of the particular State to which we belong.
- It is Victoria that wants to tax our salaries, because we happen to live here for a while.
- There is a difference in regard to the allowances we receive, but I do not propose to differentiate at present.
- The fact of State citizenship seems to have been overlooked* absolutely.

- I agree with my honorable friend that it has been overlooked. The State citizenship is not taken away because we are citizens of the Commonwealth. It is by virtue of our State citizenship that we are liable to State taxation. If I chose to draw a salary, or it might be fees - but I do not suppose I could, as lawyers who are members of Parliament are not allowed to draw fees from the Commonwealth - or if some other member of the profession who is not in Parliament, and so is more fortunate than I am in that respect, were to draw fees from theCommonwealth,' would those fees be exempt from taxation ? It would be a most grateful' thing to the profession if they were, and' indeed that must be so, if ' they are to be exempt as emoluments, because such a man is, I suppose, a Federal instrumentality just as much as an ordinary Civil servant. These people are liable by virtue of their State citizenship, but then it is said that because their means of living come from the Commonwealth Treasury, they are not to be liable in respect of that money Without discussing the matter from the technical or legal point of view, with which we are not concerned, it is liberally making- the State Treasury pay for .what the citizen, whether in regard to education or anything else, should pay for himself.

- How would the honorable senator get over the inequalities that might exist in the emoluments of Federal servants- if they all paid income tax, and if that tax was heavier in one State than it was across an artificial line in another State ?

- The inequality, if such existed, would be the fault of the States. If such a thing happened I should say it was so much the better for the Federal servant in a State where there was no income tax, or only a small one.
- There would probably be an equivalent tax in another direction.

- There might be, but even so, if the Commonwealth chose to take that into consideration, it would be one way of solving the difficulty to say, " Let the Commonwealth pay out of the Treasury this particular income tax."
- It would be deducted from the money returned to the States, and the States would be no better off.
- What- ever method is adopted, that one might probably be a solution of the difficulty.

debate.para: The Commonwealth, if it wanted to have the emoluments paid over undisturbed to its servants, might undertake to pay the income tax in the particular States for them.

talk.start.para: - I think that is the correct solution.
- At present I do not say so finally at all.
- Might there not be some other constitutional difficulty there?
- I do not know whether there would be.
- Under the financial sections of the Constitution there seems to be a possibility of a constitutional difficulty in connexion with such a proposal.

- My honorable friend may be right. I am not saying whether it is so or not, but at any rate that occurs to me as a method which might be adopted with less obvious objections than the method that has been proposed by the Government.
- But still it would be very objectionable.
- It might or might not be so. It has also to be remembered that the tax is not placed upon the individual as a Federal officer.
- He is taxed as a State citizen.

- Precisely so. He is taxed in respect of his income like any of the rest of us in the State, and it is an extraordinary thing to me that that income after it reaches his hands - he receiving the protection of the State in respect of his individuality - should be exempt from taxation simply because it comes but of the Commonwealth Treasury.
- If the States can tax part of his salary, does not that carry with it the further power to tax the whole of it?
- There must be uniformity of tax. If a State attempted to appropriate the whole of the salary of a Federal officer--
- Or to tax Federal officers as Federal officers.

- Yes - such an act would be a violation, not so much of the Constitution, as of the highest principles of the common law. It would be a legislative fraud which could not endure for one instant, nor would it be assented to.
- Supposing the States said that all persons following the occupation of postmaster must pav a tax of £i$o a year?
- They could not say it, and, if they did, no such Bill would be assented to.
- Why does the honorable and learned senator say that they could not do so as a matter of right if they chose?

- One of the elements of the State Parliaments is the King. The King is also a factor in our legislation, and one could not attribute such an act to any Parliament which consists of the King, the House of Assembly, and the Legislative Council, any more than one could assert that assent would be given to a Bill of this Parliament to confiscate the property of a State.
- If the Parliament decided to do it, it is very unlikely that the King would refuse to assent to it.
- I am astonished to hear an honorable gentleman in the responsible position of Vice-President of the Executive Council make such a statement. The thing is utterly outrageous.
- I thank the honorable and learned senator.
- Would not the Governor of the State act on the advice of his responsible Ministers?
- He would not be bound to do so in such a case, and he certainly would not be so weak as not to reserve a Bill of that kind for the assent of His Majesty himself.
- The discussion of such a possibility is fruitless.

- I am glad to have these objections raised, because we want to elucidate this problem as much as we can, but Senator Trenwith has put his finger on the fatal defect. You could not predicate it of any Legislature, or of that portion of the Legislature which is also a portion of our Legislature - the King. It is of no practical moment to us to imagine the possibility of a state of things happening which would lead to the entire disruption of the Empire.
- When we have the Premiers of some of the States talking of taking forcible possession of the post-offices we can predicate a good many things.
- I am sure the honorable senator does not take that threat seriously, any more than I do, and therefore, perhaps, he will forgive me for not dwelling upon it.

- The phrase, from the judgment of Chief Justice Marshall in McCulloch v. Maryland, " The power of taxation is the power of destruction," was applied to the State of Maryland taxing, not a Federal officer, but a bank the property of the Federal Government.

- I, as a lawyer, think that the decision in Mcculloch v. Maryland has been given undue weight in the consideration of these matters. The State having the power to tax its own citizens - a power undiminished and unaffected by the Constitution - and these persons being its own citizens and having an income, however derived, which gets into their hands and then loses the glamour attaching to Commonwealth money, we should expect something in. the Constitution to prevent their taxation if that were intended. In the Constitution there is nothing forbidding such taxation. All the State powers are conserved, except those which are expressly taken away. There is nothing, so far as I can see, to take away from a State its power to tax its own citizens. TIle Constitution is an Act of Parliament, and is to be construed like every other Act of Parliament. That is the view which was taken, and if I may say so with all deference, rightly taken by the Chief Justice in the Tasmanian case, in which, in answer to an argument which was being put by Mr. Glynn, he said -

quote.para: That would be all very well if the Constitution had said so. . . We have to decide what the Legislature means by what it has now said'.

debate.para: Mr. Glynn was contending for inferences, and so on, in connexion with a claim which was made by Tasmania to some Customs duties collected in Victoria, and the Court then supported the argument that there is no clear intention in the Constitution that duties shall go to the State of consumption. I hold that in the Constitution there is no expressed intention that the citizens of the States shall not be taxed in respect of moneys they receive from the Commonwealth as well as other moneys. Again, in giving judgment, the Chief Justice said -

quote.para: We were invited by Mr. Glynn to apply in construing the .Constitution some higher rule of construction, to look beyond the letter of the Constitution.

debate.para: The Court declined to look beyond the letter of the Constitution in that case. Why should it not have equally declined to look beyond it in such a case as the one under discussion ? The Court rejected the opinion that the ordinary rules for considering Acts of Parliament do not apply to the Constitution. Perhaps honorable senators will agree that that is a fairly sound view to take. But, instead of that being done, we had imported from America this doctrine described by Mr. Justice Isaacs, when at the Bar, as a doctrine of implied prohibitions invented by Chief Justice Marshall. I do not want to discuss that, except to say that it does not mean, as I gathered Senator St. Ledger thought, an implication derivable from the language of the Constitution. This is a doctrine invented, as Mr. Justice Isaacs said, at that time, or really evolved from the judicial consciousness, in order to meet what was considered to be a particular defect in relation to the American Constitution, which, otherwise it was supposed, and probably rightly so, could not be met. But it was a doctrine altogether outside the written Constitution, and it was exten'ded here to the Public Service as an instrumentality. I venture humbly to agree with what Mr. Justice Isaacs and Mr. Justice Higgins said - that this tax involved no interference in any respect with the efficiency in the discharge of their duties of the Commonwealth public servants. It was not directed against them in any way, and I cannot do better than read two or three words Mr. Justice Isaacs uttered near the end of his judgment, and to which I am unable to add anything better, taking the broad view which he did, which, I think, will commend itself to all of us -

quote.para: But the State Act touches no function of the officer, it intrudes its operations into no public act that he performs, it affixes no condition, and imposes no qualification upon the discharge of his duties, it makes no demand upon his public time, and seeks no service at his hands; it merely requires of him his just share of the ordinary burden of his fellow citizens in return for the protection and benefits the State affords him. If this be so, the Statute attacked in each case has not intruded into the exclusive domain of Commonwealth executive action, it has not invaded the powers, interfered with the means, or interrupted the operations of the central Government, and, therefore, should, in my judgment, be declared to stand as a valid exercise of State legislative authority.

debate.para: The questions as put by the learned Chief Justice seem to involve a little confusion. The first question was -

quote.para: Is the High Court the final arbiter of the law with respect to the special case mentioned in section 74 of the Constitution?

debate.para: The question as to that really is : Is this a subject-matter within section 74 of the Constitution ? There is no dispute that when we get a judgment, or whatever it may be, under section 74, the restriction on appeal lies. The question is : Is this such a judgment within the meaning of section 74? The second question which the Chief Justice put was -

quote.para: Could a State in the exercise of its legislative and Executive authority restrict the exercise of the similar authority of the Commonwealth, and viceversa

debate.para: That, I venture to submit, is not the question as it would commend itself to most of us. The question really is : Can the' Commonwealth, or is there anything to enable the Commonwealth to, without express power in the Constitution, give immunity to any individual or class of State citizens from the lawful taxation, by the State, of its citizens? Putting aside the law, with which we cannot deal; putting aside technical interpretations and the consideration of cases to which much reference has been made, and with which we cannot deal ; and looking at it from the broad point of view as citizens of the Commonwealth, and as citizens of our respective States, I venture to say that the answer to that question must be "No; the Commonwealth cannot do anything of the kind."

talk.start.para: - Does the honorable and learned senator say that that is a question which the Court ought to have asked ?
- I say that is the real question in controversy.
- The reference to the Commonwealth giving an immunity seems to suggest legislation.
- No, by the Constitution. If the Constitution authorizes it, the Parliament may legislate to define the immunity. If, however, the Constitution does give the immunity it cannot take it away.
- No, but we can define it.

- Let me point out that the immunity is not an immunity of the Commonwealth, but of the individual. It rests on the doctrine tr> which reference has been made that the Federal public servant is a Commonwealth instrumentality; but it is the individual who has the light, and it is he alone who can waive it if anybody can.
- But who is to decide the question whether a citizen is or is not immune? That is the crucial point.
- At present the Privy Council has decided that he is not immune.
- And the High Court has decided that he is.
- What are we asked to do? We are asked to adopt the decision of the Privy Council, and to say that the Federal public servant is not immune.
- That he is not to be immune in the future.

- My honorable friend is always acute. That is so, and that is one of the defects of this-" particular measure. If the individual is not immune, then he is not immune as to the past, and as to the position up to the present date we are still left to face the difficulty which has arisen. There is this further point, that if the Bill is merely of that character - partial - the question is whether, from that point of view, it is one that we can safely pass.
- Which 'Court is he to obey? That is another point.
- !But we are not settling that.
- It is a difficult question.

- From my point of view, I see no difficulty. I think that the difficulty arose on the decision in the cases of Deakin and Lyne, when the High Court declined to give special leave to appeal to the Privy Council. Look.ing at the nature of the inquiry, and at the fact that every person in the Public Service of the Commonwealth, from the. Judges themselves - even the Governor-General, because I see that- he is to be expressly exempt under the Bill - down to the humblest official whose salary would come within the ambit of a State income tax, was affected, I venture to think that it would have been wise, on that wide ground alone, to have had the matter referred to a tribunal which was not in the Commonwealth, and which was altogether independent, for ultimate decision. I think that, probably, if that had been done it would have saved the whole of this trouble, and no question would have been raised as to the propriety or otherwise of the High Court bowing to the decision of the Privy Council. Of course, I am not prepared to say anything now as to the application for a certificate. I rather take the view, looking at what the two new Justices of the High Court have said - I allude to Mr. Justice Isaacs and Mr. Justice Higgins - that it might have been as well to have solved the difficulty by a reconsideration, uninfluenced by that jealousy to which reference has been made, but from the point of view of trying to secure a solution, by giving weight to what the Privy Council has said on the merits of the question, and by making some approach, at any rate, to die views of the eminent Judges who are the latest additions to the High Court Bench. I regret that course was not adopted, and it is not for me to say any more about it.
- Why should not that course be taken now?
- But the honorable senator has always contended that the High Court should be supreme on constitutional matters.
- I tried to secure that that should be so, but did not succeed in getting it. We now have to deal with things as they are.
- I think that four of the Judges of the High Court said that they had not power to give leave to appeal to the Privy Council.
- I do not think that they went so far as that, but they said that they saw no reason why leave to appeal should be given.
- They unanimously refused.

- They refused unanimously, but not because they had not the power. Leave had been refused before, and, as Mr. Justice Higgins said, to give a certificate would only have been a roundabout way of yielding to the judgment of the Privy Council.
- Is there any objection to our looking' to the High Court to get us out of the impasse to which they have brought us?
- The High Court is the objection.

- Another matter to be considered is that what we are asked to do by this Bill is an act of justice, by making persons liable to income tax to which the High Court says they are not liable - to declare, in fact, that the Privy Council was right, and that these people ought to be subject to taxation. I entirely agree with the view that it is just that this immunity should be swept away, but I doubt whether this is the right way to do it, or whether this Bill will have the effect of doing it. The position would be no better if this were a Bill to declare that the Privy Council was right. If the judgment of the Privy Council is right, it stands for what it is. If the judgment of the High Court is right, it stands for what it is, and we must find the remedy in the Constitution itself. If an amendment of the Constitution were necessary, it would have to be made.
- What is the position of a Commonwealth servant or a member of Parliament who is compelled, through circumstances, to spend a portion of his time in one State and a portion in another ?
- That would be a matter of adjustment, I presume, between the States concerned.
- Suppose that the State which a member of Parliament represents demands income tax, and that the State in which Parliament sits also demands it?
- Then there arises the question of how much is earned in each particular State.
- And the member of Parliament has to fight both the States to find out.

- He would have to fight them both under this Bill. The difficulty cannot be got over by such a measure as this. But my point is that this Bill would not make the position any better. Another matter to be considered is that this is a Bill to impose taxation upon those who are supposed to be not at present liable to pay the tax in question. The Bill does not fix the tax, but leaves it to be fixed by the States. We impose a liability by this Bill, and we refer it to the States' to say how much, within certain limits, should be paid. It is a matter for consideration, therefore, how far this Bill is one which is properly before us at the present time. It is undoubtedly a taxation Bill. It is a Bill to impose taxation.
- And differential taxation at that.

- I mention that because it is a pity that we should go on with the measure if it is not properly before us. It would be very much better for us to discuss this point in all its bearings than to have it thrust upon us in some Other way by another place. Then, again, as has been suggested, the measure is partial and incomplete. If it is to be uniform, surely it ought to apply to all officers. But there is an exception in the case of the Governor-General. There may be constitutional reasons for that, but a measure of this kind ought to be made general, unless there is some overriding reason why it should not be. If the judgment of the Privy Council stood, it would be a question whether it applied to the Governor-General or not, and it would not be for us, and it would not be for the States, apart from constitutional questions, to declare that immunity. A State might declare immunity from its own taxes, but it is not for the Commonwealth Parliament to do so.
- Would the honorable and learned senator inform the Senate whether the salaries of officers of the Imperial fleet serving in' Australian waters would be subject to State income tax?
- I really do not know. It may be if they are resident in a State, and deriving income there, they should be just as much liable as other citizens, but, as I say, I do not know.
- They have never been taxed, I believe.
- A State may exempt them, and, possibly, they are exempt from income tax on other grounds.

- Is the honorable senator aware that the New South Wales Government would not take income tax on the parliamentary allowances of Federal members? Some of us put the amount of the allowance in. our returns, and the Government exempted them.

- I am. glad to hear it. I do not know whether it. has been done in my State, but I will mention it to the authorities, and see whether they are prepared to follow so good, an example. There is another point worthy of consideration as to our powers.. It relates to the form of clause 2,. which, provides -

quote.para: That taxation by a State,, on common withe other salaries earned within the- State of, (a), the official salaries of officers of the Commonwealth earned in the State after the commencement of this Act; and (d) the allowances paid after the commencement of this Act. of members of the Parliament elected in the State shall' not, if the taxation is not at a higher rate or to~~ a greater extent than is imposed on other salaries of the same amount earned in the State,, be deemed [e) to be an interference with the exercise of any power of the Commonwealth.

debate.para: The High Court has said that to. tax the salaries of Federal officers is such an interference. Can we say that it is not? Because, if we can, and do, we shall certainly be flying in the face of all that we suppose that we can do under the Constitution, and; flying in the face also of the principle of the Constitution that the High Court is a co-ordinate factor in the Constitution with the Parliament. There are three bodies - the Executive, the Legislature, and the Judiciary ; and if we can by an Act of Parliament say that, although the High Court has pronounced a particular judgment, we declare that it shall be of no avail, we shall very seriously interfere with the position of the High Court. I invite honorable senators to consider the question from that point of view.

talk.start.para: - This is a Bill to-. " bash " the High Court on the head !
- I do not put it in that way, but it is a Bill to confirm the judgment of the Privy Council. That is one thing. It is also a Bill, in.< express terms, to overrule the decision of the High Court.
- If the High Court is right in declaring that the matter involved is a constitutional one, can this Bill be of any avail ?
